Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I sat at my desk, the weight of the black robe heavy on my shoulders, when the clerk rushed in with a thick file. “Emergency motion, Judge. They need your ruling within the hour.” I glanced at the clock—forty-five minutes until the children would gather in the synagogue classroom, waiting for me, their rabbi, to guide them through this week’s Torah portion. My mind raced. As a judge, I was expected to pore over every detail, to ensure justice was served swiftly and fairly, especially in urgent matters like this. But as a rabbi, I was the anchor for these children, the one who made ancient words come alive, who answered their questions and shaped their faith. I could not be in two places at once. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Religious school in 30 minutes.” My heart pounded. I imagined the disappointed faces of the children, the anxious parties awaiting my ruling. Both roles demanded my full presence, my undivided attention. I stared at the file, then at my Torah notes, feeling the impossible pull of duty from both sides, unsure which part of myself to betray.
